abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Fifth Oil Palm
            Development Project for Cote d'Ivoire was
            unsatisfactory. The project failed to achieve its
            objectives, institutional development was negligible,
            sustainability is unlikely, and the performance of the Bank
            was satisfactory while the Borrower's was
            unsatisfactory. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, support prices for producers during an
            extended period of low market external prices for a
            commodity, coupled with an over-valued currency, are
            non-sustainable, even by the healthiest of economies and can
            have devastating consequences for agencies responsible for
            bearing the cost of such support. Second, the sustainability
            of a government commercial organization is closely linked to
            a favorable economic framework, appropriate pricing
            policies, and the availability of strong managerial and
            financial skills related to the size of its operations.
            Third, technical assistance personnel in charge of
            implementing project activities are seldom able to devote
            time to building local capacity or be advocates of major
            restructuring of the operation they manage. Finally, if no
            clear distinction is made between the social and
            profit-oriented operations through government budgets,
            supporting social activities from profits can soon become untenable.
